description: ðŸ‘‹  I am a Software Developer with experience in software testing, systems administration, project planning and team leadership. I began my career in technology as a Helpdesk Associate, then as a Computer Lab Technician, and later as a Windows Systems Administrator. While earning a Associate Degree in Network Technologies, I created a computer asset-tracking database tool for the campus IT team that helped track computers and forecast budget needs.

Later, as a Systems Administrator at Citrix Systems, I managed the computer lab hardware, data storage, and network systems. Through collaboration with a software developer I helped design and deploy a hardware management tool that increased computer lab equipment utilization and simplified budget forecasting for the team's leadership. I also built-out dev and test team environments on hardware, hypervisors and Azure, reducing time-to-deploy for dev and test activities.

I acquired bids for electrical work and network upgrades, and implemented routing and VLAN technologies to support secure dev and production systems network performance. As an Systems Admin of a globally reaching Active Directory deployment, I was responsible for network operations supporting the Engineering teams. I took the lead on several occasions to push for implementation of new features, solving issues affecting users globally, and upgrading services like SharePoint, improving user experience and productivity.

Working in an advanced software development group, coupled with my growing experiences with PowerShell, I earned a certification in Software Test Engineering from Bellevue College where I picked up Python, C#, Git, SQL, and agile software development processes. Soon after, I moved into a software testing role at Citrix, designing test plans, executing tests, submitted concrete yet succinct bug reports, and validating bug-fixes on multiple projects, simultaneously. I developed automated build-and-deploy scripts using PowerShell, and created one-button-execution UI testing using Selenium Driver and Python, detecting UI bugs and allowing more time for continued Lab Manager and Systems Admin tasks completion.

I returned to Bellevue College to complete C# Programming training and started to enjoy working with object-oriented, stronly-typed languages. Wanting to go further, I earned a certificate in Advanced Software Development in Java from Code Fellows in Seattle, WA, where I learned how to build full-stack Web Apps using HTML, CSS, JS, React, Express, SQL and No-SQL databases, as well as collaborative software development techniques including pair-programming and use of agile tools like Trello and Miro to design solutions and manage development progress.

In between classes and projects I applied my skills to my ham radio hobby by building radio-interfacing electronics and developing software to capture and transform data. For example, I made improvements and added specific, necessary features to an existing web-based form that radio operators use to transmit urgent, emergent, or logistical messages via 'email over ham radio'. I updated the UI for simplicity and accessibility including those with limited vision and limited mobility users, and refactored the code to be clean and easily readable.

In late 2022, I met an enthusiastic React developer and we jointly designed, developed, and bug tested a React SPA using common software development tools and technique, all while completely remote from each other. This project is a web-based Bingo game that allows a presenter to create a custom Bingo board and share a link to the board with their audience. The audience can then play Bingo by clicking on the board's squares to mark them as 'called'. The presenter can see the audience's boards and can call out the next square to be marked. The project is currently in development to be a full-stack app, published to Netlify and Azure App Services.

I enjoy developing software solutions for web and desktop, working with engaging people, and finding solutions that make sense for the context of the end user. I look forward to working on a diverse software development team creating and refining technical solutions and delighting customers. ðŸ‘‹

projects.title: Coordinate Conversion Utility
projects.description: As an amateur radio operator I need to be aware of several different coordinate systems to identify where I am, and where other operators might be. As a software developer I want to develop an application that will help me convert from 4 common coordinate system notations. Many hams before me have explored solving coordinate conversion in software however I enjoyed the challenge and the achievement.

projects.title: LingoBing JS
projects.description: Working with Ryan Schafer on our spare time, we re-wrote the LingoBingo project using React. We are are finishing up the first part of a v.1 release that implements MERN-stack design pattern, and will follow that with an add-on UI for Presenters to add their own words and generate a web-link to their custom-defined LingoBingo boards.

projects.title: EZ-PC Shopper
projects.description: Final project for CodeFellows Code 201 class, helps site visitors build and buy a computer system from the ground up. This project challenged me to refine my bug finding and squashing abilities, acquire a deeper understanding of CSS 3.0, and experience project management by guiding meetings, project design, and pair-programming with my team mates.

projects.title: Salmon Cookies
projects.description: Code Fellows Code 201 Lab Project Cookie Stand provided an opportunity to put together JavaScript, HTML 5, CSS 3.0 to meet the goal of presenting a new website for a ficticious, growing business. Using DOM Manipulation to edit the UI, HTML 5 Forms, and CSS features to manage images, content, and coloring style were the focus features. I enjoyed working on this project!

projects.title: LingoBingo
projects.description: One of the first web apps I worked on using C# DotNET Blazor Web Assembly. The original idea came from a webinar on audience engagement by Cindy Huggett, where she suggested presenters play Buzzword Bingo so audience members could yell BINGO when they match 5 presenter-planned buzzwords in a row. The project has been through many version, from Console application to what it is now - a live, playable Azure WebApp. I learned a lot about C#, Dot NET, and web development, which made it clear to me I wanted to learn more about building capable, fun websites!
